contents.content: The i, z, and y filters of the LSST Camera transmit infrared light, making it possible to see stars hidden behind the gas and dust of a nebula, and to detect very faint red stars, which give off more light in near-infrared light than visible red light.

The Trifid Nebula is a dense cloud of gas and dust. The glowing gas in the nebula is the bright cloud, and the non-glowing gas and dust appears to be very dark areas. If the Trifid Nebula was observed using visible light alone, many of the stars within it would be hidden from view.

The images of the Trifid Nebula were taken using the g, r, and z filters. After the greyscale images were taken they were assigned colors, with the g filter image colorized blue, the r filter image colorized green, and the z (infrared) filter image colorized red.

images.figText: The greyscale and colorized images for the g, r, and z filters are shown above. Credit: T.A. Rector, (University of Alaska Anchorage) and CTIO/NOAO/NSF.

question.title: Question #1
question.label: Compare the three black and white images of the Trifid Nebula, taken through g, r, and z filters. What differences in the brightness of gas and amount of stars do you notice between the three images?

question.title: Question #1
question.label: If only infrared filters are used (like the i, z, and y filters), would you be able to determine which stars are the ones hidden by the cloud of gas and dust? Explain your reasoning.
